title: Kirchhoff junction - why current at Y is 0 or down

content.question: A circuit consists of a battery and four resistors, two of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and two of resistance <math alttext="3 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. Points <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> are located at junctions where three wires meet, and Point <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is between points <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>. Which of the following claims about the current <math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> at Point <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is correct, and what evidence or reasoning helps support the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is zero. Points <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> are at the same potential.
<math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is zero. The currents in all four resistors are equal.

<math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is toward the bottom of the figure. Point <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is at a higher potential than Point <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and Point <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is at a higher potential than Point <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>.

<math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is toward the bottom of the figure. The resistors of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> have more current than the resistors of resistance <math alttext="3 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> is toward the bottom of the figure. The resistors of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> have more current than the resistors of resistance <math alttext="3 R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></math>.
